MOTION Rensselaer Union 55th Student Senate Date: October 7, 2024 | Motion #2 WHEREAS the 2023-2024 Elections Commission has detailed many issues with the 2024 Grand Marshal Week Election, which included issues properly synching candidates names to the Elections Website and reﬂecting candidates preferred names on the ballot 1 ; WHEREAS The 2023-2024 Election Commission struggled to maintain a sufﬁcient number of poll workers during the 2024 GM Week Elections, as evident in the Elections Commission motion to allow candidates to serve as poll workers during the GM runoff election 1 ; WHEREAS the 2023-2024 Elections Commission collaborated with Rensselaer Union System Administrators to maintain digital election infrastructure and to resolve issues during the 2024 GM Week Elections such as the potential votes dropped in the Rensselaer Union Voting System (RUVS), changing candidates names to their preferred names, and the voter lists by class; and WHEREAS many of these changes would be addressed by changes in the policy of the Rensselaer Union, and the 55th Student Senate believes these changes should reside outside of the election policy for Freshmen and GM Week Elections; It shall hereby be the policy of the Rensselaer Student Union that: The following policy be made part of the standing policy of the Rensselaer Union and this action of the 55th Student Senate be referred to as the “2024 Election Reform Policy”. SECTION 1: DEFINITIONS. The following terms be deﬁned as follows, which shall only be used for the purposes of this policy and shall not be applied elsewhere in the Union: (a) ‘Elections Commission’ shall refer to the body of the Student Senate empowered to carry out student government elections; (b) ‘System Administrator’ shall refer to Rensselaer students employed in a part time capacity to administer the technical systems of the Union; 1 https://sites.google.com/view/rpistugov/student-senate/committees/elections-commission?authu  ser=0

 (c) ‘Union Staff’ shall refer to full time, paid employees of the Union, which includes but is not limited to the Director of the Union and their assistants; and (d) ‘Student Workers’ shall refer to Rensselaer students, employed by the Union, as according to decisions by the Executive Board, and managed by the Union staff. SECTION 2: UNION STAFF. The Union Staff will work alongside the Election Commission to create additional work opportunities for Student Workers during the Election. (a) The Election Commission will designate which hours will be available for the Student Workers to aid in the election and what election-related tasks may be performed. (i) No Student Workers shall be placed under any direction but that of an appointed member of the Election Commission during poll sitting. (b) The Union staff will be responsible for deciding how many hours will be permitted for individual workers, the veriﬁcation of these hours, and the communication of these opportunities. (i) Any additional logistical requirements to facilitate these workers being made available will be a Union staff responsibility. (c) No beneﬁts provided by the Union Executive Board or the Election Commission to volunteers shall be provided to Student Workers, nor to any other workers who are compensated monetarily. (d) As per the Union Constitution, the Union Executive Board shall be responsible for budgeting and operational decisions not explicitly delegated to the Election Commision. (e) No Union Staff or Student Worker shall provide an unequal advantage to any candidate at any point during the election period. SECTION 3: DIGITAL TOOLS. Digital systems of the election shall include but are not limited to the Rensselaer Union Voting System and the admin panel of the Election Website. (a) The Elections Commission shall designate additional digital systems as needed prior to an election. (b) The designated Union staff overseeing the System Administrators may be granted complete access to the digital system; no other Union staff may be granted complete access. (c) No member of the Union who has declared their candidacy for any ofﬁce shall be permitted access to any digital system of the Election System.

 (i) No member of the Union may assume an elected ofﬁce as a result of an election where they possessed access to the digital election system, unless they assume an empty position following the appropriate appointment procedures after the election. SECTION 4: WEBTECH-SYSTEM ADMIN AGREEMENT. The previous agreement of relationships between the System Administrators and the Student Senate’s Web Technologies Group shall remain as a non-binding document guiding the two groups with their respective responsibilities 2 . (d) Should any agreements conﬂict with the yearly election policy, the yearly election policy shall be the superseding policy. SECTION 5: SYSTEM ADMINISTRATORS. (a) For the period of time between the opening of the election and the closing, as deﬁned by the Election Commission, the System Administrators shall designate an individual on their team as a contact for the Election Commission. (i) The exact responsibilities of this individual in regards to elections shall be determined in the yearly election policy or via additional motions passed within the Elections Commission, which shall be made public. (ii) This individual shall have the election infrastructure as their ﬁrst priority during the duration of the Election. (b) The existing procedure to determine the priorities and work allocation for the System Administrators shall be modiﬁed in consideration to the following, in regards to the Elections Commission digital systems: (i) The Union Executive Board and Union Staff Members shall take into consideration the state of the Election digital infrastructure when determining the priorities of the System Administrators. (1) No priority shall be set that would prevent the System Administrators from ensuring a working election infrastructure prior to an election; (2) The Lead System Administrator, in collaboration with the Union staff, shall be responsible for determining if clause (1) applies, and if so, shall be responsible to adjust the priorities as such; and (3) The current priorities of the System Administrator shall be made available to the Election Commission on request. 2 https://drive.google.com/ﬁle/d/1hgAOdJGaoe4VGSSfmw6Uof-eKXNSTYSG/view

 (c) No System Administrator shall provide any advantage, unequal treatment, or an endorsement to a candidate or group of candidates. S O M OVED B Y A ND S ECONDED B Y V OTE Ria Massoni Andrew Wu 11-00-01 Graduate Senator Class of 2027 Senator  P ASSES | F AILS

segments.text: MOTION Rensselaer Union 55th Student Senate Date: October 7, 2024 | Motion #2 WHEREAS the 2023-2024 Elections Commission has detailed many issues with the 2024 Grand Marshal Week Election, which included issues properly synching candidates names to the Elections Website and reﬂecting candidates preferred names on the ballot 1 ; WHEREAS The 2023-2024 Election Commission struggled to maintain a sufﬁcient number of poll workers during the 2024 GM Week Elections, as evident in the Elections Commission motion to allow candidates to serve as poll workers during the GM runoff election 1 ; WHEREAS the 2023-2024 Elections Commission collaborated with Rensselaer Union System Administrators to maintain digital election infrastructure and to resolve issues during the 2024 GM Week Elections such as the potential votes dropped in the Rensselaer Union Voting System (RUVS), changing candidates names to their preferred names, and the voter lists by class; and WHEREAS many of these changes would be addressed by changes in the policy of the Rensselaer Union, and the 55th Student Senate believes these changes should reside outside of the election policy for Freshmen and GM Week Elections; It shall hereby be the policy of the Rensselaer Student Union that: The following policy be made part of the standing policy of the Rensselaer Union and this action of the 55th Student Senate be referred to as the “2024 Election Reform Policy”

SECTION 1: DEFINITIONS The following terms be deﬁned as follows, which shall only be used for the purposes of this policy and shall not be applied elsewhere in the Union: (a) ‘Elections Commission’ shall refer to the body of the Student Senate empowered to carry out student government elections; (b) ‘System Administrator’ shall refer to Rensselaer students employed in a part time capacity to administer the technical systems of the Union; 1 https://sites com/view/rpistugov/student-senate/committees/elections-commission?authu  ser=0

 (c) ‘Union Staff’ shall refer to full time, paid employees of the Union, which includes but is not limited to the Director of the Union and their assistants; and (d) ‘Student Workers’ shall refer to Rensselaer students, employed by the Union, as according to decisions by the Executive Board, and managed by the Union staff SECTION 2: UNION STAFF The Union Staff will work alongside the Election Commission to create additional work opportunities for Student Workers during the Election (a) The Election Commission will designate which hours will be available for the Student Workers to aid in the election and what election-related tasks may be performed (i) No Student Workers shall be placed under any direction but that of an appointed member of the Election Commission during poll sitting (b) The Union staff will be responsible for deciding how many hours will be permitted for individual workers, the veriﬁcation of these hours, and the communication of these opportunities (i) Any additional logistical requirements to facilitate these workers being made available will be a Union staff responsibility (c) No beneﬁts provided by the Union Executive Board or the Election Commission to volunteers shall be provided to Student Workers, nor to any other workers who are compensated monetarily (d) As per the Union Constitution, the Union Executive Board shall be responsible for budgeting and operational decisions not explicitly delegated to the Election Commision (e) No Union Staff or Student Worker shall provide an unequal advantage to any candidate at any point during the election period

SECTION 3: DIGITAL TOOLS Digital systems of the election shall include but are not limited to the Rensselaer Union Voting System and the admin panel of the Election Website (a) The Elections Commission shall designate additional digital systems as needed prior to an election (b) The designated Union staff overseeing the System Administrators may be granted complete access to the digital system; no other Union staff may be granted complete access (c) No member of the Union who has declared their candidacy for any ofﬁce shall be permitted access to any digital system of the Election System (i) No member of the Union may assume an elected ofﬁce as a result of an election where they possessed access to the digital election system, unless they assume an empty position following the appropriate appointment procedures after the election SECTION 4: WEBTECH-SYSTEM ADMIN AGREEMENT The previous agreement of relationships between the System Administrators and the Student Senate’s Web Technologies Group shall remain as a non-binding document guiding the two groups with their respective responsibilities 2 (d) Should any agreements conﬂict with the yearly election policy, the yearly election policy shall be the superseding policy SECTION 5: SYSTEM ADMINISTRATORS (a) For the period of time between the opening of the election and the closing, as deﬁned by the Election Commission, the System Administrators shall designate an individual on their team as a contact for the Election Commission (i) The exact responsibilities of this individual in regards to elections shall be determined in the yearly election policy or via additional motions passed within the Elections Commission, which shall be made public (ii) This individual shall have the election infrastructure as their ﬁrst priority during the duration of the Election (b) The existing procedure to determine the priorities and work allocation for the System Administrators shall be modiﬁed in consideration to the following, in regards to the Elections Commission digital systems: (i) The Union Executive Board and Union Staff Members shall take into consideration the state of the Election digital infrastructure when determining the priorities of the System Administrators (1) No priority shall be set that would prevent the System Administrators from ensuring a working election infrastructure prior to an election; (2) The Lead System Administrator, in collaboration with the Union staff, shall be responsible for determining if clause (1) applies, and if so, shall be responsible to adjust the priorities as such; and (3) The current priorities of the System Administrator shall be made available to the Election Commission on request
2 https://drive

com/ﬁle/d/1hgAOdJGaoe4VGSSfmw6Uof-eKXNSTYSG/view

 (c) No System Administrator shall provide any advantage, unequal treatment, or an endorsement to a candidate or group of candidates
S O M OVED B Y A ND S ECONDED B Y V OTE Ria Massoni Andrew Wu 11-00-01 Graduate Senator Class of 2027 Senator  P ASSES | F AILS

MOTION   Rensselaer   Union   56th   Student   Senate   Date:   03/25/2025   |   Motion   #56-01     WHEREAS   the   Class   Councils   and   the   Graduate   Council   do   not   currently   have   a   mailing   list   to   effectively   reach   their   constituents ;   WHEREAS   the   lack   of   a   mailing   list   is   hindering   the   Class   Council's   ability   to   communicate   important   information   to   their   respective   constituents;   WHEREAS   the   Student   Senate   has   determined   that   it   is   necessary   for   the   Union   to   adopt   a   policy   to   address   this   issue   and   improve   communication ;     WHEREAS   the   Union   Administration   currently   constructs   class   lists   for   elections;   and   WHEREAS   the   Student   Senate   is   the   chief   legislative   and   policymaking   branch   of   the   Rensselaer   Union;     It   shall   hereby   be   the   policy   of   the   Rensselaer   Union   that:     The   following   policy   be   made   part   of   the   standing   policy   of   the   Rensselaer   Union   and   this   action   of   the   56th   Student   Senate   be   referred   to   as   the   “2025   Class   Mailing   List   Policy”.   Deﬁnitions   not   contained   within   are   found   in   the   “Common   Organizational   Terms   Act   of   2024”. 1   SECTION   1:   Mailing   Lists.   The   Mailing   Lists   that   will   be   created   or   impacted   by   this   policy   and   their   memberships   are   deﬁned   below:   (a)   The   Undergraduate   Class   Mailing   Lists   (i)   Four   separate   Mailing   Lists,   one   for   each   of   the   current   undergraduate   class   years.   (ii)   These   shall   be   referred   to   as   the   "Class   Council   Lists".   (b)   The   Graduate   Class   Mailing   List   (i)   A   Mailing   List   for   the   entire   Graduate   student   body   of   the   Union.   (ii)   This   shall   be   referred   to   as   the   "Graduate   Class   List".   (c)   The   Fraternity   and   Sorority   Mailing   List   1   https://rpi.box.com/v/commondefinitions  

   (i)   A   Mailing   List   for   all   Greek-afﬁliated   members   of   the   Union.   (d)   Membership   will   be   drawn   within   4   weeks   of   the   end   of   the   general   election   and   updated   according   to   the   registration   of   Union   members   by   the   class   or   afﬁliation   registered   to   vote.   (i)   The   Union   Administration   will   make   reasonable   efforts   to   continuously   update   the   list   throughout   the   academic   year.   (e)   Mailing   Lists   that   are   not   speciﬁed   in   this   policy   will   be   unaffected.   (f)   This   policy   will   be   superseded   by   any   Institute-wide   policy   for   mailing   lists.     Section   2:   Roles   and   Responsibilities   of   Union   Administration.   The   Union   Administration   will   be   responsible   for   the   creation,   membership,   and   administration   of   the   aforementioned   mailing   lists.   (a)   They   may   direct   a   Union   System   Administrator   to   populate   the   mailing   lists   with   the   previously   deﬁned   membership.   (b)   They   will   be   responsible   for   access   and   approvals   to   the   mailing   lists,   which   will   be   updated   to   reﬂect   changes   from   the   general   elections   or   vacancies.   (c)   They   will   be   responsible   for   drafting   the   membership   of   the   aforementioned   lists.   (d)   They   will   be   responsible   for   the   interpretation   of   the   deﬁnitions   in   this   policy.   (e)   They   will   be   responsible   for   the   technical   details   of   the   implementation.     Section   3:   Access   and   Approval .   Access   will   be   deﬁned   as   the   ability   to   send   to   a   mailing   list.   Approval   will   be   deﬁned   as   the   technical   ability   to   approve   the   email   to   be   mass-sent   to   the   students.   (a)   Class   Council   Lists   (i)   The   President   of   each   respective   Class   Council   will   have   access   to   the   mailing   list;   the   individual   Class   Council   may   designate   additional   individuals.   (ii)   The   Undergraduate   President   will   be   able   to   approve   all   emails.   (iii)   The   Union   Administration   will   take   the   primary   role   in   approving   all   emails   sent.   (b)   Graduate   Class   List   (i)   The   President   of   the   Graduate   Council   will   have   access   to   and   be   able   to   approve   all   emails;   they   may   designate   additional   individuals   to   have   access   but   not   approval   to   the   mailing   list.  

   (c)   The   Grand   Marshal   and   President   of   the   Union   will   have   access   and   approval   to   send   emails   to   all   mailing   lists   created   under   this   policy.     Section   4:   Suspension   of   Access.   (a)   The   Undergraduate   Council   may   suspend   the   access   of   any   Class   Council   to   their   respective   class   list   for   inappropriate   usage,   with   appeal   power   resting   in   the   Judicial   Board.     (i)   The   Union   Administration   may   temporarily   suspend   the   access   of   any   Class   Council   to   their   respective   class   list   for   inappropriate   usage,   pending   a   vote   of   the   Undergraduate   Council.   (b)   The   Union   Administration   may   temporarily   suspend   access   to   any   mailing   list   for   inappropriate   usage,   established   by   this   policy,   other   than   the   Class   Council   lists,   pending   review   of   the   Judicial   Board.   (c)   Inappropriate   access   shall   be   deﬁned   as   sending   out   emails   in   violation   of   Union   policy,   Institute   policy,   federal   or   state   laws,   or   other   abuse   of   the   email,   including   but   not   limited   to,   excessive   non-relevant   emails,   personal   gain,   distributing   sensitive   information,   sending   messages   that   contain   hate   speech,   harassment,   discrimination   or   threats,   false   information,   personal   attacks,   forwarding   malicious   link   or   attachments,   or   messaging   that   attempts   to   manipulate   the   election.                 S O   M OVED   B Y             V OTE   BY   R OLL -C ALL   Web   Technologies   Group     15-00-01   03-00-00       P ASSES    |    F AILS     Presented   By       Williams   Chen       Web   Technologies   Group   Chairperson

a8f5256d54475cd687d4b43f6dbfb258.file_path: files/56-08 UPAC Union Mailing List Policy April 15th.pdf
a8f5256d54475cd687d4b43f6dbfb258.text:
MOTION   Rensselaer   Union   56th   Student   Senate   Date:   04/15/2025   |   Motion   #56-08     WHEREAS   the   Union   Programming   and   Activities   Committee   (UPAC)   hosts   campus-wide   events   such   as   GM   Week,   Winter   Carnival,   and   other   events   that   reach   the   entire   student   population;     WHEREAS   the   Student   Senate   has   previously   directly   legislated   on   the   matter   of   Union   mailing   lists   in   the   “2025   Class   Mailing   List   Policy” 1   to   empower   Union   bodies   with   access   to   greater   communication;   It   shall   hereby   be   the   policy   of   the   Rensselaer   Union   that:     The   following   policy   be   made   part   of   the   standing   policy   of   the   Rensselaer   Union   and   this   action   of   the   56th   Student   Senate   be   referred   to   as   the   “2025   UPAC   Union   Mailing   List    Policy”.     SECTION   1:   Organization   (a)   The   organization   impacted   by   this   policy   will   be   the   Executive   Board's   Union   Programs   and   Activities   Committee,   hereafter   referred   to   as   UPAC.   (b)   UPAC   subcommittees   shall   refer   to   the   following   subcommittees   of   UPAC,    not   including   any   future   changes   in   the   structure   of   UPAC.   (i)   UPAC   General   (ii)   UPAC   Cinema   (iii)   UPAC   Concerts   (iv)   UPAC   Comedy   (v)   UPAC   Winter   Carnival   (vi)   UPAC   GM   Week   (c)   Any   organizations   not   mentioned   in   this   policy   will   be   unaffected   by   this   policy.   SECTION   2:   Mailing   List   (a)   The   Mailing   List   that   will   be   impacted   by   this   policy   will   be   the   “Union   Events   1   https://rpi.app.box.com/v/rpisg/file/1814701794634    

   Mailing   List”,   a   list   that   contains   Union   Events.   (b)   Any   mailing   list   not   mentioned   in   this   policy   will   be   unaffected   by   this   policy.   SECTION   3:   Empowerment   to   Send   Emails.    Approval   will   be   deﬁned   as   the   technical   ability   to   approve   the   email   to   be   mass-sent   to   the   students.   (a)   The   UPAC   subcommittees   shall   collectively   be   empowered   to   send   a   limited   quantity   of   emails   to   the   Union   Events   Mailing   List.   (i)   The   limit   shall   be   15   emails   per   academic   year,   split   up   at   the   discretion   of   the   UPAC   committees.   (1)   Any   additional   requests   shall   only   be   approved   by   the   subcommittee's   Student   Activities   Resource   Person   (SARP)   or   a   member   of   the   Union   Administrative   Staff.   (ii)   The   subcommittee's   Student   Activities   Resource   Person   (SARP)   or   a   member   of   the   Union   Administrative   Staff   will   take   a   primary   role   in   approving   all   emails.   Section   4:   Suspension   of   Access.   (a)   The   Executive   Board   may   suspend   the   access   of   any   UPAC   subcommittee   to   the   Union   Events   Mailing   List,   with   appeal   power   resting   in   the   Judicial   Board.     (b)   The   Union   Administration   may   temporarily   restrict   the   access   of   any   UPAC   subcommittee   to   the   Union   Events   Mailing   List   for   inappropriate   usage,   established   by   this   policy,   pending   review   of   the   Judicial   Board.   (c)   Inappropriate   access   shall   be   deﬁned   as   sending   out   emails   in   violation   of   Union   policy,   Institute   policy,   federal   or   state   laws,   or   other   abuse   of   the   email,   including   but   not   limited   to,   excessive   non-relevant   emails,   personal   gain,   distributing   sensitive   information,   sending   messages   that   contain   hate   speech,   harassment,   discrimination   or   threats,   false   information,   personal   attacks,   forwarding   malicious   link   or   attachments,   or   messaging   that   attempts   to   manipulate   the   election.             S O   M OVED   B Y             V OTE   BY   U NANIMOUS   C ONSENT   Web   Technologies   Group     Unanimous   Consent  

   03-00-00       P ASSES    |    F AILS     Presented   By       Williams   Chen       Web   Technologies   Group   Chairperson

state   laws,   or   other   abuse   of   the   email,   including   but   not   limited   to,   excessive   non-relevant   emails,   personal   gain,   distributing   sensitive   information,   sending   messages   that   contain   hate   speech,   harassment,   discrimination   or   threats,   false   information,   personal   attacks,   forwarding   malicious   link   or   attachments,   or   messaging   that   attempts   to   manipulate   the   election S O   M OVED   B Y             V OTE   BY   U NANIMOUS   C ONSENT   Web   Technologies   Group     Unanimous   Consent

626a8851dbd9e82885f23afc7aa753c1.text:
AN   ACT     To   establish   further   guidelines   on   mandatory   Title   IX   trainings   as   established   by   the   Rensselaer   Union   Student   Senate   in   Senate   Motion   55-18.     Be   it   enacted   as   Rensselaer   Union   policy   by   the   Student   Senate,     SECTION   1.   Definitions   &   Title   This   Act   may   be   cited   as   the   “Title   IX   Training   Reform   Act”.   The   following   definitions   shall   only   pertain   to   this   Act,   unless   explicitly   referenced   by   some   other   Act:   (1)   The   term   “required   club”   shall   refer   to   a   Union   club   or   organization   whose   officers   are   mandated   to   attend   Title   IX   training   under   federal   or   state   law,   the   Rensselaer   Student   Union   2024   Title   IX   and   Bystander   Intervention   Requir ement ,   or   some   other   Union   policy .   (2)   The   term   “required   member”   shall   refer   to   a   member   of   a   required   club   who   is   mandated   to   attend   Title   IX   training   under   federal   or   state   law,   the   Rensselaer   Student   Union   2024   Title   IX   and   Bystander   Intervention   Requir ement ,   or   some   other   Union   policy .   (a)   The   Executive   Board   shall   make   determinations   for   which   members   of   a   required   club   are   considered   required   members,   based   on   their   good   faith   judgement   in   compliance   with   New   York   state   law.   (3)   The   term   “Title   IX   Training”   shall   refer   to   any   training,   session,   or   other   curriculum   which   fulfills   the   Rensselaer   Student   Union   2024   Title   IX   and   Bystander   Intervention   Requir ement .   (4)   The   term   “failed   fulfillment”   shall   refer   to   a   case   in   which,   in   a   given   academic   year,   less   than   two-thirds   of   a   required   club’ s   required   members   attend   Title   IX   Training   or   are   exempted.      

   SECTION   2.   Proper   Notification   and   Exemption   (1)   For   all   required   clubs,   any   member   who   is   required   to   attend   the   training   may   exempt   themselves   from   the   requirement   detailed   in   the   Rensselaer   Student   Union   2024   Title   IX   and   Bystander   Intervention   Requir ement   by   providing   evidence   that   they   have,   within   the   last   year,   participated   in   training   that   would   satisfy   the   requirement,   regardless   of   whether   such   training   was   sanctioned   by   the   Rensselaer   Union.   (a)   The   Executive   Board   shall   provide   proper   notice   of   this   clause   within   reasonable   proximity   to   the   time   where   they   first   announce   Title   IX   Training   in   a   given   semester ,   and   they   shall   provide   adequate   means   by   which   members   may   submit   exemption   requests.   (2)   Each   academic   semester ,   not   including   the   summer   semester ,   must   contain   at   least   four   Title   IX   Trainings   sponsored   by   the   Rensselaer   Union,   as   shall   be   implemented   by   the   Executive   Board.   Every   training   in   a   given   academic   semester   must   not   all   occur   on   the   same   day   of   the   week,   and   at   least   one   must   occur   past   4PM.   (a)   If   a   Title   IX   Training   is   announced   less   than   five   business   days   prior   to   the   day   of   its   scheduled   occurrence,   it   shall   not   be   counted   towards   the   required   number   of   trainings.   (b)   If   the   requirements   of   the   above   clause   are   not   fulfilled   in   a   given   semester ,   no   required   club   may   be   penalized   in   whole   or   in   part   for   the   failure   of   their   members   to   attend   Title   IX   Trainings   in   that   semester .   (c)   The   Executive   Board   shall   not   be   penalized   nor   held   in   violation   of   Union   policy   for   the   failure   to   fulfill   the   requirements   of   the   above   clause,   should   they   have   acted   in   good   faith   in   the   attempted   implementation   of   the   above   clause.   SECTION   3.   Penalties   (1)   The   Rensselaer   Union   Executive   Board   shall   determine   all   penalties   to   all   clubs   within   the   bounds   laid   within   this   section   and   Act,   with   right   of   appeal   to   the   Rensselaer   Union   Judicial   Board.   (2)   A   required   club   which   fails   fulfillment   for   the   first   time   shall   be   penalized   with   no   less   than   a   written   warning,   beyond   which   the   Executive   Board   may   consider   additional   penalties   on   a   case   by   case   basis.  

  (a)   Any   such   additional   penalties   enacted   on   this   club   may   not   include   suspension   or   disaf filiation   unless   prior   disciplinary   actions   have   been   taken   with   a   continuance   of   the   required   club   failing   fulfillment.   (3)   Upon   a   third   consecutive   academic   year   of   a   required   club   failing   fulfillment,   the   Executive   Board   shall,   in   a   timely   manner ,   consider   the   placement   of   the   relevant   club   on   probation.   (a)   This   clause   shall   not   be   construed   as   restricting   any   further   penalties   on   the   relevant   club(s)   in   such   a   case.   SECTION   4.   Implementation   This   Act   shall   go   into   effect   in   the   next   academic   year   after   this   policy   is   passed   by   the   Student   Senate,   where   a   given   academic   year   is   defined   as   starting   in   the   fall   semester .

b2134255f89281bbdb9dc0f1e0f91697.file_path: files/Union Judicial and Adjudicative Reform Policy [JAR Policy].pdf
b2134255f89281bbdb9dc0f1e0f91697.text:
AN   ACT       To   standardize   the   classification   and   handling   of   adjudicative   actions   across   the   Union.     Be   it   enacted   as   Rensselaer   Union   policy   by   the   Student   Senate,     SECTION   1.   Short   Title   &   Promulgation     1.   All   the   following   shall   refer   to   this   policy   of   the   Rensselaer   Union;   a.   “Rensselaer   Union   Judicial   and   Adjudicative   Reform   Policy   [Union   JAR   Policy]”   b.   “Adjudicative   Actions   for   Rensselaer   Union   Orgs   Reform   2024   Action”     2.   Definitions   throughout   are   defined   in   the   ‘Common   Organizational   Act   of   2024’     3.   On   passage   of   this   act   by   the   Student   Senate,   a   copy   shall   be   distributed   to   the   Officers   of   the   Union,   the   Director   of   the   Union,   and   the   Dean   of   Students   office     SECTION   2.   Definition   of   Types   of   Judicial   Cases       1.   For   the   purposes   of   the   Rensselaer   Union   operations,   two   categories   of   student   conduct   cases   heard   by   the   Union   Judicial   Board   are   established:   Disciplinary   and   Civil     2.   Disciplinary;   cases   allegedly   violations   of   the   Student   Handbook   of   Rights   and   Responsibilities   or   other   policies   established   by   the   Institute.   a.   Procedures   on   handling   these   cases   are   recognized   as   the   responsibility   of   the   Dean   of   Students   Office   by   the   Union.   b.   The   Judicial   Board   shall   make   information   about   these   procedures   public   where   applicable,   in   consultation   with   the   Dean   of   Students.   c.   Disciplinary   cases,   as   they   relate   to   Union,   are   the   exclusive   jurisdiction   of   the   Judicial   Board,   and   the   Dean   of   Students   Office.   No   other   Union   body   will   form   any   sub-bodies   to   handle   them,   nor   pass   policies   that   would   handle   those   cases   without   approval   of   the   Judicial   Board   or   Dean   of   Students   Office.     3.   Civil;   cases   alleging   violations   of   the   Union   Constitution,   bylaws   of   Union   bodies,   Union   policies,   Union   guidelines,   Union   procedures,   or   any   other   legislation   of   Union   bodies.   a.   Procedures   on   handling   these   cases   are   to   be   part   of   the   Judicial   Board   bylaws,   and   public   record.   b.   Cases   alleging   violations   of   the   Union   Constitution,   or   Union   bylaws,   shall   be   considered   “constitutional”   cases,   and   handled   as   a   subset   of   civil   cases   with   applicable   procedures.    

   c.   Civil   cases   may   be   handled   by   a   different   Union   body   before   being   appealed   to   the   Judicial   Board;     4.   Disciplinary   and   Civil   cases   shall   be   considered   separate   for   purposes   of   double   jeopardy.   a.   The   only   application   of   this   clause   shall   be   the   following:   The   initiation   or   resolution   of   a   civil   case   shall   not   be   used   as   a   reason   to   prevent   the   initiation   or   resolution   of   a   disciplinary   case,   and   vice   versa.   An   individual   may   have   a   civil   and   disciplinary   case   open   against   them   for   the   same   action   but   each   case   must   be   initiated   and   will   be   pursued   separately.   b.   This   clause   shall   not   be   interpreted   to   establish   any   generally   accepted   principle   of   “double   jeopardy”   over   the   Judicial   System   established   in   the   Student   Handbook.       SECTION   3.   Definition   of   Adjudicative   Actions   against   Union   Organizations       1.   During   regular   operations,   the   Union   may   take   certain   actions   that   are   judicial   in   nature.   For   this   policy,   and   for   all   Union   operations   and   further   policies,   “adjudicative   actions   of   the   Union”   or   “Union   adjudicative   actions”   shall   refer   to   actions   taken   by   any   Union   body   that   have   the   following   effects   :   a.   Probation   or   Suspension   of   a   Union   organization   b.   Monetary   Fine   c.   Any   other   action   that   restricts   access   to   Union   resources   for   an   organization   or   Union   member   as   a   result   of   a   breach   of   Union   policy,   Union   procedures   or   Union   guidelines.     2.   “Adjudicative   actions”   are   a   distinct   and   separate   category   from   Judicial   actions   of   the   Judicial   board   granted   by   the   Student   Handbook   of   Rights   and   Responsibilities.     a.   Adjudicative   actions   of   the   Union   are   distinct   actions   from   the   judicial   actions   of   the   Institute;   any   such   actions   are   not   to   be   inferred   as   part   of   the   Student   Handbook   of   Rights   and   Responsibilities   disciplinary   proceedings.         3.   Adjudicative   actions   shall   not   include   regular   operational   actions   of   Union   bodies,   including   non-punitive   budgetary   decisions   and   budgetary   appeals.     4.   In   no   case   shall   any   Union   body   take   action   that   prevents   an   individual   eligible   under   the   Union   Constitution   from   becoming   a   member   of   the   Union,   nor   shall   any   action   be   taken   that   prevents   them   from   fulfilling   the   requirements   to   meet   the   definition   of   a   member   of   the   Union.   a.   This   clause   shall   not   apply   for   cases   in   which   a   Union   body   upholds   a   decision   made   by   an   external   body   which   meets   the   criteria   above.     SECTION   4.   Right   of   Union   Organizations   to   Fair   Process     1.   No   Union   body   shall   impose   any   Union   adjudicative   actions   on   any   Union   organization   or   member   of   the   Union   without   the   following   rights   being   given   to   all   parties   subject   to   the   action:     a.   Rights   to   grounds;    

  i.   Before   any   proceedings   may   begin,   the   Union   organization   or   Union   member   facing   adjudicative   actions   has   a   right   to   be   provided   a   copy   and   location   of   the   Union   policy,   procedure   or   guideline   they   are   alleged   to   have   violated.     ii.   Refusal   by   a   Student   government   member   to   provide   said   grounds   is   grounds   for   removal.       b.   Rights   to   prior   notification;   i.   Before   any   proceedings   may   begin,   the   Union   organization   or   Union   member   facing   adjudicative   actions   has   a   right   to   be   informed   of   the   proceedings.     c.   Right   to   notice   of   appeal;   i.   The   Union   organization   or   Union   member   facing   Union   adjudicative   actions   shall   be   notified   during   proceedings   of   their   right   to   appeal   the   decision   after   it   is   reached   to   the   Judicial   Board.     d.   Right   to   orderly   and   prescribed   process;     i.   Any   proceedings   must   follow   a   written   procedure,   provided   to   all   parties   involved   ii.   If   proceedings   do   not   exist,   the   creation,   approval,   and   distribution   of   proceedings   must   be   the   first   act   of   any   such   proceedings.   iii.   Proceedings   may   contain   language   to   allow   alterations   in   special   circumstances.       e.   Right   to   timeliness   i.   Unless   otherwise   stated,   any   proceedings   on   Union   adjudicative   actions   must   finish   within   a   month   of   proceedings   start.     2.   Any   Union   policy   or   procedure   that   removes   the   prior   rights   is   abrogated;   any   Union   policy   or   procedure   that   imposes   adjudicative   action   is   amended   to   include   the   above   rights.     3.   Failure   to   provide   one   of   these   rights   shall   not   be   considered   in   itself   to   nullify   a   Union   adjudicative   action,   but   shall   be   clear   grounds   for   appeal   to   the   Judicial   Board     4.   This   section   shall   not   apply   to   the   Union   Judicial   Board.     SECTION   5.   Notification   of   Judicial   Actions     1.   After   a   Union   adjudicative   action   is   placed   on   a   Union   organization   or   Union   member,   the   leadership   or   Union   member   should   receive   a   written   notification   of   the   adjudicative   action   and   the   actions   they   may   take   in   response.       2.   The   body   placing   the   adjudicative   actions   shall   be   responsible   for   ensuring   this   notification   of   right   to   appeal   is   made.   Failure   to   notify   of   right   to   appeal   shall   be   considered   a   violation   of   Union   policy,   and   subject   to   referral   to   the   Judicial   Board   for   penalties.   The   Judicial   Board   shall    

  determine   which   member   of   that   body   had   the   reasonable   requirement   to   make   this   notification.       3.   Failure   to   respond   to   this   notification   within   a   reasonable   timeframe   is   the   equivalent   of   accepting   the   action.     4.   Accepting   an   adjudicative   action   does   not   remove   the   right   of   appeal   at   a   later   date.       5.   This   section   shall   not   apply   to   Union   organizations   without   recognized   leadership.       SECTION   6.   Elaboration   of   the   Right   to   Appeal       1.   Any   civil   case   may   be   appealed   to   the   Judicial   Board,   as   per   the   Union   Constitution.     2.   Nothing   in   this   policy   shall   be   interpreted   to   set   requirements   beyond   those   of   the   Union   Constitution   on   the   right   to   appeal   civil   cases   to   the   Judicial   Board.     3.   The   “Grounds   for   Appeal”   as   established   in   the   Student   Handbook   of   Rights   &   Responsibilities   shall   not   be   restricted   in   any   ways   by   this   policy.

    4 Disciplinary   and   Civil   cases   shall   be   considered   separate   for   purposes   of   double   jeopardy The   only   application   of   this   clause   shall   be   the   following:   The   initiation   or   resolution   of   a   civil   case   shall   not   be   used   as   a   reason   to   prevent   the   initiation   or   resolution   of   a   disciplinary   case,   and   vice   versa An   individual   may   have   a   civil   and   disciplinary   case   open   against   them   for   the   same   action   but   each   case   must   be   initiated   and   will   be   pursued   separately This   clause   shall   not   be   interpreted   to   establish   any   generally   accepted   principle   of   “double   jeopardy”   over   the   Judicial   System   established   in   the   Student   Handbook SECTION   3 Definition   of   Adjudicative   Actions   against   Union   Organizations       1 During   regular   operations,   the   Union   may   take   certain   actions   that   are   judicial   in   nature For   this   policy,   and   for   all   Union   operations   and   further   policies,   “adjudicative   actions   of   the   Union”   or   “Union   adjudicative   actions”   shall   refer   to   actions   taken   by   any   Union   body   that   have   the   following   effects   :   a Probation   or   Suspension   of   a   Union   organization   b
Monetary   Fine   c

Any   other   action   that   restricts   access   to   Union   resources   for   an   organization   or   Union   member   as   a   result   of   a   breach   of   Union   policy,   Union   procedures   or   Union   guidelines

“Adjudicative   actions”   are   a   distinct   and   separate   category   from   Judicial   actions   of   the   Judicial   board   granted   by   the   Student   Handbook   of   Rights   and   Responsibilities Adjudicative   actions   of   the   Union   are   distinct   actions   from   the   judicial   actions   of   the   Institute;   any   such   actions   are   not   to   be   inferred   as   part   of   the   Student   Handbook   of   Rights   and   Responsibilities   disciplinary   proceedings Adjudicative   actions   shall   not   include   regular   operational   actions   of   Union   bodies,   including   non-punitive   budgetary   decisions   and   budgetary   appeals In   no   case   shall   any   Union   body   take   action   that   prevents   an   individual   eligible   under   the   Union   Constitution   from   becoming   a   member   of   the   Union,   nor   shall   any   action   be   taken   that   prevents   them   from   fulfilling   the   requirements   to   meet   the   definition   of   a   member   of   the   Union This   clause   shall   not   apply   for   cases   in   which   a   Union   body   upholds   a   decision   made   by   an   external   body   which   meets   the   criteria   above SECTION   4 Right   of   Union   Organizations   to   Fair   Process     1 No   Union   body   shall   impose   any   Union   adjudicative   actions   on   any   Union   organization   or   member   of   the   Union   without   the   following   rights   being   given   to   all   parties   subject   to   the   action:     a Rights   to   grounds;    

  i Before   any   proceedings   may   begin,   the   Union   organization   or   Union   member   facing   adjudicative   actions   has   a   right   to   be   provided   a   copy   and   location   of   the   Union   policy,   procedure   or   guideline   they   are   alleged   to   have   violated Refusal   by   a   Student   government   member   to   provide   said   grounds   is   grounds   for   removal Rights   to   prior   notification;   i Before   any   proceedings   may   begin,   the   Union   organization   or   Union   member   facing   adjudicative   actions   has   a   right   to   be   informed   of   the   proceedings Right   to   notice   of   appeal;   i The   Union   organization   or   Union   member   facing   Union   adjudicative   actions   shall   be   notified   during   proceedings   of   their   right   to   appeal   the   decision   after   it   is   reached   to   the   Judicial   Board Right   to   orderly   and   prescribed   process;     i Any   proceedings   must   follow   a   written   procedure,   provided   to   all   parties   involved   ii If   proceedings   do   not   exist,   the   creation,   approval,   and   distribution   of   proceedings   must   be   the   first   act   of   any   such   proceedings Proceedings   may   contain   language   to   allow   alterations   in   special   circumstances

Right   to   timeliness   i Unless   otherwise   stated,   any   proceedings   on   Union   adjudicative   actions   must   finish   within   a   month   of   proceedings   start Any   Union   policy   or   procedure   that   removes   the   prior   rights   is   abrogated;   any   Union   policy   or   procedure   that   imposes   adjudicative   action   is   amended   to   include   the   above   rights Failure   to   provide   one   of   these   rights   shall   not   be   considered   in   itself   to   nullify   a   Union   adjudicative   action,   but   shall   be   clear   grounds   for   appeal   to   the   Judicial   Board     4 This   section   shall   not   apply   to   the   Union   Judicial   Board SECTION   5 Notification   of   Judicial   Actions     1 After   a   Union   adjudicative   action   is   placed   on   a   Union   organization   or   Union   member,   the   leadership   or   Union   member   should   receive   a   written   notification   of   the   adjudicative   action   and   the   actions   they   may   take   in   response The   body   placing   the   adjudicative   actions   shall   be   responsible   for   ensuring   this   notification   of   right   to   appeal   is   made Failure   to   notify   of   right   to   appeal   shall   be   considered   a   violation   of   Union   policy,   and   subject   to   referral   to   the   Judicial   Board   for   penalties The   Judicial   Board   shall    

  determine   which   member   of   that   body   had   the   reasonable   requirement   to   make   this   notification Failure   to   respond   to   this   notification   within   a   reasonable   timeframe   is   the   equivalent   of   accepting   the   action Accepting   an   adjudicative   action   does   not   remove   the   right   of   appeal   at   a   later   date This   section   shall   not   apply   to   Union   organizations   without   recognized   leadership SECTION   6 Elaboration   of   the   Right   to   Appeal       1 Any   civil   case   may   be   appealed   to   the   Judicial   Board,   as   per   the   Union   Constitution Nothing   in   this   policy   shall   be   interpreted   to   set   requirements   beyond   those   of   the   Union   Constitution   on   the   right   to   appeal   civil   cases   to   the   Judicial   Board The   “Grounds   for   Appeal”   as   established   in   the   Student   Handbook   of   Rights   &   Responsibilities   shall   not   be   restricted   in   any   ways   by   this   policy

MOTION Rensselaer Union 55th Student Senate Date: 4/29/24| Motion #4 WHEREAS the New York State Food Donation & Food Scraps Recycling Law (2019) states that large generators of food scraps must donate excess edible food and, if within 25 miles of an organics-composting facility, compost all remaining excess food; WHEREAS the Rensselaer Union does not currently donate or compost all excess food; WHEREAS donations of excess food can help those in need; WHEREAS composting excess food has environmental beneﬁts; The 55th Student Senate hereby RESOLVES that it shall be the policy of the Rensselaer Union: 1. To donate all excess edible food to: a. Members of the Union and b. Food-relief organizations and 2. To compost all remaining excess food. The 55th Student Senate hereby RESOLVES: 1. To direct the Facilities and Services Committee to work with the Executive Board on the implementation of this legislation. S O M OVED B Y P RESENTED B Y V OTE Facilities & Services  Committee Ramond Lin ‘24  FSC Chairperson 14-0-0 P ASSES | F AILS S IGNED B Y Vivian Rost-Nasshan,  158th Grand Marshal F&SC Committee Membership  Gabriel Jacoby-Cooper—YAY This motion PASSES out of the Facilities  & Services Committee with 2 YAY  votes, 0 NAY votes, and 0 abstentions.

 Ramond Lin—YAY

2bd3ea0082bc786845487a329005e244.file_path: files/Rensselaer Student Union 2024 Title IX and Bystander Intervention Requirement.pdf
2bd3ea0082bc786845487a329005e244.text:
MOTION Rensselaer Union 55th Student Senate Date: September 9, 2024 | Motion #4 WHEREAS College campuses across the nation face substantial issues of sexual harassment, sexual misconduct, and sexual assault 1 ; WHEREAS The Institute’s 2023 Annual Security and Fire Safety Report states that nine forcible Sex Offenses occurred on or adjacent to campus in 2022 (the most recent year reported). Six of these offenses were rape, and ﬁve of those six occurred in on-campus residential facilities 2 ; WHEREAS The Institute requires all students to complete training regarding federal and campus Title IX policy and procedures, sexual misconduct, sexual harassment, consent, bystander intervention, and related resources, as mandated by federal and state laws 3 ; WHEREAS The aforementioned trainings are exclusively offered through online modules; WHEREAS the Student Health Center and the Counseling Center developed Rensselaer’s Bystander Intervention Training in 2013 to address six common areas of risky behavior among college students: substance abuse, hazing, sexual misconduct, intimate partner violence, mental health emergencies, and physical emergencies 4 ; WHEREAS The Student Health Center collaborated with the Division of Student Life in 2018 to develop a Bystander Intervention Peer Education Program to train undergraduate students on the aforementioned six risky behaviors in addition to “diversity/equity/inclusion, campus policies and procedures, on- and off-campus resources, and facilitation skills”, which focused “on developing the skills to actively recognize and safely intervene where high-risk behaviors are present” 4 ; WHEREAS Trainings through the Bystander Intervention Peer Education Program have not occurred since the COVID-19 pandemic began in March 2020; 4 https://info.rpi.edu/sites/default/ﬁles/Rensselaer%20Biennial%20Report%20Jan.%202018%20-%20Jan.%202020.pdf 3 https://info.rpi.edu/dean-students/09/01/2021/required-sexual-misconduct-prevention-training-module 2 https://rpi.app.box.com/s/vuj8s3z7i8uz4ojjyvcscqg7f2nekvd8 1 https://www.aauw.org/resources/research/crossing-the-line-sexual-harassment-at-school/

 WHEREAS For student clubs and organizations to receive bystander intervention training, they currently must take the initiative to email the Student Health Center’s Ofﬁce of Health Promotions to request it 5 ; WHEREAS New York State Education Law §6447(6), which went into effect July 1, 2016, states that all colleges and universities must require that, in addition to completing the training that is required for all students 6 , “each student leader and ofﬁcer of student organizations recognized by or registered with the institution, as well as those seeking recognition by the institution, complete training on domestic violence, dating violence, stalking, or sexual assault prevention prior to receiving recognition or registration” 7 ; WHEREAS Bystander Intervention Training and Title IX training used to be required for “all ofﬁcers of organizations classiﬁed by the Union” and “all ofﬁcers of a newly forming organization, according to Rensselaer Union Guidelines and Procedures, § 7.4, March 2022 . Topics of the Bystander Intervention Training included “domestic violence, dating violence, stalking, sexual assault prevention”, and Title IX Training topics included “how Rensselaer responds to allegations of the preceding.” Should a Union recognized or afﬁliated organization fail to attend either of the two required trainings, their funds were frozen (if Union funded) and they were barred from using Union meeting spaces and other Union resources 8 ; WHEREAS The most recent version of the Rensselaer Union Guidelines and Procedures, updated by the Rensselaer Union Executive Board in December 2023, does not include any mention of the Bystander Intervention Training requirement or the Title IX Training requirement that were included in the previous versions 9 ; WHEREAS The 54th Student Senate made recommendations to the Institute in November 2023 regarding student reports of “a campus climate 10 that is prone to unsafe situations and sexual misconduct” and a lack of adequate training, requesting that Title IX training for incoming students be conducted in person and requesting additional bystander intervention training for student leaders 11 ; 11 https://docs.google.com/document/d/1B757V66Cso_LIjEddewsllwOJROd3oiBhW90Iiyv2RA 10 https://rpi.app.box.com/v/CampusClimateSurveySummary 9 https://rpi.box.com/s/lf6gtcvea59rhsd1ofys4ny1keevdwsn 8 https://rpi.box.com/s/f7o2o4m02qqaqj5ydxx8v33m5stt3pzn 7 https://www.nysenate.gov/legislation/laws/EDN/6447 6 https://www.nysed.gov/sites/default/ﬁles/article-129-b-guidance.pdf 5 https://studenthealth.rpi.edu/list-services/ofﬁce-health-promotion

 WHEREAS The Student Senate believes that, beyond the legal requirement, the additional bystander intervention and Title IX training for student leaders will positively affect the membership of the Union, creating a safer environment on campus; WHEREAS The Student Senate is empowered as the legislative branch of the Union, with power of initiative over all areas that affect the Union and the ability to set policy; It shall hereby be the policy of the Rensselaer Student Union that: SECTION 1. All student leaders are required to attend additional Title IX and bystander intervention training on an annual basis. SECTION 2. Student leaders shall be deﬁned as: (a) Leadership of all Union organizations deﬁned in the Rensselaer Union Constitution. (i) At a minimum, this shall include all ofﬁcer positions deﬁned by the organization in their bylaws or in the Rensselaer Union Constitution. Union organizations may elect to include additional members in this deﬁnition, should it be relevant to their role. (b) Leadership of Union Clubs. (i) The Rensselaer Union Executive Board shall be the sole body responsible for: 1. Determining the deﬁnition of leadership of Union clubs — accounting for relevant sections of Union and Institute policy, state and federal law — , which shall be applicable only to this policy. 2. Communicating this requirement to Union club leadership; 3. Tracking this requirement; and 4. Determining when completion of this requirement has been met. (c) This deﬁnition shall only be used for the purpose of this policy and shall not be applied elsewhere in the Union. SECTION 3. Additional Title IX and bystander intervention training shall be deﬁned as Title IX and bystander intervention training offered by the Institute to the student body besides that which is already required for all students.

 (a) At a minimum, this training shall include domestic violence, dating violence, stalking, or sexual assault prevention, as is mandated by New York state law. (i) This training shall strive to address the topics that were previously offered during bystander intervention training for student leaders, which includes substance abuse; hazing; sexual misconduct and harassment; Title IX policies and procedures; intimate partner violence; mental health emergencies; physical emergencies; diversity, equity, and inclusion; campus policies and procedures; on and off campus resources; and facilitation skills to actively recognize and safely intervene in high risk situations. 4 (b) At the beginning of each academic year, the Director of the Union, their assistants, representatives of the Rensselaer Union Executive Board, and representatives of the Student Senate shall collaborate to identify and coordinate such a training program with the Institute. (i) If no such training can be successfully identiﬁed, then sections (1) and (2) of this policy shall not apply for the academic year. 1. In this case, the Director of the Union, their assistants, representatives of the Rensselaer Union Executive Board, and representatives of the Student Senate shall endeavor to make such training available for the following year. (c) This deﬁnition shall only be used for the purpose of this policy and shall not be applied elsewhere in the Union. SECTION 4. No Union organization shall impose any penalties if student leaders fail to meet these requirements during the 2024-2025 academic year. SECTION 5. This policy may be cited as the “Rensselaer Student Union 2024 Title IX and Bystander Intervention Requirement”, or “Union Title IX and Bystander Intervention Requirement”. S O M OVED B Y The Student Life Committee Passed 6-0-1 on September 9, 2024 V OTE 12-00-00 P ASSES | F AILS And Presented By Ria Massoni  Student Life Committee Chair

MOTION Rensselaer Union 54th Student Senate Date: January 8-22, 2024 | Motion #1 WHEREAS the modern academic setting is increasingly flexible, with changes such as  transfer credits, the Arch, and coterminal programs, and WHEREAS these changes to the traditional academic path have led to decreased  representation in Student Government, affecting its ability to serve students, The Rensselaer Union 54th Student Senate hereby RESOLVES: 1.To approve the following amendments to the Rensselaer Union Constitution to be   placed on the ballot during Grand Marshal Week 2024: AMENDED: R.U. Const. art. XI, § 1. Should  the  position  of  Grand  Marshal  become  vacant,  within  two  weeks  the   Student Senate shall appoint a new Grand Marshal from within the membership of   the Union. Their appointment shall require the approval of ⅔ vote of the Student   Senate.  The  Chairperson  of  the  Judicial  Board  will  preside  over  this   appointment. Until the new Grand Marshal is appointed, the Student Senate   by-laws  shall  dictate  who  will  assume  the  remaining  duties  of  the  Grand   Marshal. AMENDED: R.U. Const. art. XI, § 2. Should the position of President of the Union become vacant, within two weeks the   Executive Board shall appoint from within the membership of the Union  a new  President. Their appointment shall be confirmed by a ⅔ vote of the Student   Senate. The Executive Board by-laws shall dictate who will preside over the   Executive Board until the new President of the Union is confirmed. ADDED: R.U. Const. art. VIII, § 14. a.If any candidate knows they will be unable to serve their full term, another   candidate may run for a successive position alongside the primary candidate   during a general election. b.Both candidates must be eligible for election and to hold office as defined in   this Constitution. c.The successive candidate shall serve for a term beginning upon the date of the   effective resignation of their predecessor and ending with the conclusion of the  

next general election for their respective position. SO MOVED BY AND SECONDED BY VOTE BY ROLL-CALL Vivian Rost-Nasshan ‘26 Chris Roe 14-01-02 Independent Senator Class of 2026 SenatorPASSES  |  FAILS SIGNED BY Ben Viner, 157th Grand Marshal

segments.text: MOTION Rensselaer Union 54th Student Senate Date: January 8-22, 2024 | Motion #1 WHEREAS the modern academic setting is increasingly flexible, with changes such as  transfer credits, the Arch, and coterminal programs, and WHEREAS these changes to the traditional academic path have led to decreased  representation in Student Government, affecting its ability to serve students, The Rensselaer Union 54th Student Senate hereby RESOLVES: 1 To approve the following amendments to the Rensselaer Union Constitution to be   placed on the ballot during Grand Marshal Week 2024: AMENDED: R Should  the  position  of  Grand  Marshal  become  vacant,  within  two  weeks  the   Student Senate shall appoint a new Grand Marshal from within the membership of   the Union Their appointment shall require the approval of ⅔ vote of the Student   Senate

The  Chairperson  of  the  Judicial  Board  will  preside  over  this   appointment Until the new Grand Marshal is appointed, the Student Senate   by-laws  shall  dictate  who  will  assume  the  remaining  duties  of  the  Grand   Marshal Should the position of President of the Union become vacant, within two weeks the   Executive Board shall appoint from within the membership of the Union  a new  President Their appointment shall be confirmed by a ⅔ vote of the Student   Senate The Executive Board by-laws shall dictate who will preside over the   Executive Board until the new President of the Union is confirmed If any candidate knows they will be unable to serve their full term, another   candidate may run for a successive position alongside the primary candidate   during a general election Both candidates must be eligible for election and to hold office as defined in   this Constitution The successive candidate shall serve for a term beginning upon the date of the   effective resignation of their predecessor and ending with the conclusion of the  

next general election for their respective position SO MOVED BY AND SECONDED BY VOTE BY ROLL-CALL Vivian Rost-Nasshan ‘26 Chris Roe 14-01-02 Independent Senator Class of 2026 SenatorPASSES  |  FAILS SIGNED BY Ben Viner, 157th Grand Marshal

MOTION Rensselaer Union 54th Student Senate Date: April 26, 2023 | Motion #1  WHEREAS the campus speed limit is relatively unknown among the student body, and     WHEREAS many vehicles exceed the campus speed limit, and    WHEREAS many micro-mobility devices are unsafely operated inside Rensselaer buildings     The Rensselaer Union 54th Student Senate hereby RESOLVES :     1.To approve the attached Handbook of Student Rights and Responsibilities  Amendment    a.AMENDED: Vehicular, Micro-Mobility, and Parking Rules and  Regulations:    Micro-mobility is defined as a mode of transport that includes  bikes, scooters, skateboards, hoverboards, segways, and  unicycles.    Electric micro-mobility is defined as an electrified micro-mobility  device.    All motor vehicles (including motorcycles and mopeds) must be  registered. Parking at Rensselaer is limited, and student vehicles are   restricted by permit to specific areas on campus.    Parking permits and copies of the driving and parking regulations  are available from the Parking Office or at:  https://info.rpi.edu/parking-and-transportation.    Parking regulations can be modified by the Parking and  Transportation Office to meet changing needs. Student ticket 

appeals are decided by the Student Motor Vehicle Court.    Freshmen living in a residence hall are prohibited from bringing a  motor vehicle to the Rensselaer campus. Vehicles parked on or  contingent to the campus must comply with campus and municipal  parking regulations or  may be ticketed and towed at the owner's expense.      All vehicles and micro-mobility devices must adhere to the  campus speed limit of 15 miles per hour unless otherwise posted.   Micro-mobility devices, excluding assisted mobility devices, are  prohibited from operating in buildings.   SO MOVED BY VOTE Ramond Lin Julie 7-1-0 PASSES  |  FAILS

MOTION Rensselaer Union 54th Student Senate Date: April 26, 2023 | Motion #1  WHEREAS the campus speed limit is relatively unknown among the student body, and     WHEREAS many vehicles exceed the campus speed limit, and    WHEREAS many micro-mobility devices are unsafely operated inside Rensselaer buildings     The Rensselaer Union 54th Student Senate hereby RESOLVES :     1 To approve the attached Handbook of Student Rights and Responsibilities  Amendment    a AMENDED: Vehicular, Micro-Mobility, and Parking Rules and  Regulations:    Micro-mobility is defined as a mode of transport that includes  bikes, scooters, skateboards, hoverboards, segways, and  unicycles Electric micro-mobility is defined as an electrified micro-mobility  device All motor vehicles (including motorcycles and mopeds) must be  registered Parking at Rensselaer is limited, and student vehicles are   restricted by permit to specific areas on campus Parking permits and copies of the driving and parking regulations  are available from the Parking Office or at:  https://info edu/parking-and-transportation Parking regulations can be modified by the Parking and  Transportation Office to meet changing needs Student ticket 

appeals are decided by the Student Motor Vehicle Court Freshmen living in a residence hall are prohibited from bringing a  motor vehicle to the Rensselaer campus Vehicles parked on or  contingent to the campus must comply with campus and municipal  parking regulations or  may be ticketed and towed at the owner's expense All vehicles and micro-mobility devices must adhere to the  campus speed limit of 15 miles per hour unless otherwise posted Micro-mobility devices, excluding assisted mobility devices, are  prohibited from operating in buildings SO MOVED BY VOTE Ramond Lin Julie 7-1-0 PASSES  |  FAILS

50dd6e1de2b5b229b58827b23d55bfa9.text: MOTION Rensselaer Union 54th Student Senate Date: October 16, 2023 | Motion #1: Supplemental Course Material Cost Reduction Resolution “Supplemental course material costs” hereinafter refers to the student expenses required  to succeed in a specific course that are not included in tuition or provided to students  including but not limited to textbooks, account subscriptions, software, raw materials, and  electronic components. WHEREAS Students are required to purchase “access codes” for online homework and  assessment administration, WHEREAS Required online textbook access can expire, prohibiting students from  referencing their previous textbooks, WHEREAS Students who choose to buy or rent a physical copy of a textbook may not be  able complete required assignments, WHEREAS It has been reported that students are spending upwards of $400 on  supplemental materials  for one single course, and WHEREAS These supplemental costs can create a financial bias against economically  disadvantaged students, The Rensselaer Union 54th Student Senate hereby RESOLVES: 1.To be the principal executor of its initiative to reduce supplemental course material   costs for students under the direction of its Academic Affairs Committee, and 2.To extend its full support to administrative efforts aligning with this initiative. SO MOVED BY AND SECONDED BY VOTE Timothy Miles ‘24 Henry Hanson 12–00–00 Interfraternity Council Senator Class of 2026 SenatorPASSES  |  FAILS SIGNED BY Ben Viner, 157th Grand Marshal

MOTION   Rensselaer Union 49th Student Senate   Date: ​  May 2, 2018 |  ​ Motion #1       WHEREAS Grand Marshal Week 2018 Elections included a number of human errors,   including, but not limited to, the omission of amendments, the appearance of duplicate   names on the ballot, the inclusion of write-in candidates on the ballot, and the omission of   RPI identification checks at polling locations;   WHEREAS, on April 18, 2018, the Elections Commission released a list of its concerns with   the elections, noting that the elections were not tampered by any candidate and that the   results stood as valid;   WHEREAS, on April 22, 2018, the Rensselaer Union Judicial Board ruled that the concerns   with the elections process must be addressed and resolved for subsequent elections; and   WHEREAS the Rensselaer Union Constitution authorizes the Student Senate to establish   and maintain elections policies and procedures;   The Rensselaer Union 49th Student Senate hereby RESOLVES:   1. To establish the Elections Reform Task Force as a special committee of the 49th   Student Senate:   a. Its membership shall consist of the Grand Marshal, the Chairperson of the   Elections Commission, the Chairperson of the Web Technologies Group, a   judicial board emeritus, and three members-at-large appointed by the   Grand Marshal, and   b. It shall fulfill its purpose and present to the Student Senate, in the form of a   report and resolution, its recommendations by no later than December 31,   2018, and   2. To charge the Elections Reform Task Force with the purposes of:   a. Reviewing elections policies, including the  ​ Grand Marshal Week 2018   Elections Handbook ​ , to identify and recommend solutions to any issues with   the elections process, and   Rensselaer Union   110 8th Street, Troy, NY 12180   sg.rpi.edu  

      b. Working with the Web Technologies Group, the Rensselaer Union Systems   Administrators and Software Engineers, alumni, and other Union   organizations, to identify and recommend solutions to any technical issues   with the voting system, or to propose an alternative to the current voting   system.       S O  M OVED  B Y   A ND  S ECONDED  B Y   V OTE   Nancy Bush  ‘19   Bryan Johns  ‘19   17–0–1         P ASSES   |  F AILS             Rensselaer Union   110 8th Street, Troy, NY 12180   sg.rpi.edu  

      MOTION   Rensselaer Union 49th Student Senate   Date:  ​ May 2, 2018 |  ​ Motion #2       WHEREAS Jerry Matthews has served the Department of Public Safety for over eight   years, as Director from 2005 to 2009 and as Interim Director from 2014 to 2018;   WHEREAS he has shown a true dedication to not only protecting the students of   Rensselaer, but also engaging with them as an active member of the campus community;   WHEREAS he has played a major role in the expansion and creation of numerous safety   initiatives on campus, including growing the officer escort program during overnight shift   hours, the implementation of a campus-wide active shooter drill, and expanding the   relationship between Public Safety and the Troy Police Department;   WHEREAS he has spearheaded the initiative for Public Safety to participate in extended   outreach to students in order to make the office a more welcoming and approachable   division of campus for students;   WHEREAS his efforts and services will not be forgotten, and he will be missed by many;   The Rensselaer Union 49th Student Senate hereby RESOLVES:   1. To thank Jerry Matthews, Director of Public Safety, for his years of service to the   Rensselaer community, for his commitment to student safety and wellbeing, and   for his continued willingness to support student initiatives and programs,   2. To recognize all of the contributions that he has made to the campus as a whole,   and   3. To wish him the best in his well deserved retirement.     S O  M OVED  B Y   A ND  S ECONDED  B Y   V OTE   Nancy Bush ’19   Bryan Johns ’19   18–0–0         P ASSES   |  F AILS         Rensselaer Union   110 8th Street, Troy, NY 12180   sg.rpi.edu  

      MOTION   Rensselaer Union 49th Student Senate   Date: ​  May 2, 2018 |  ​ Motion #3     The Rensselaer Union 49th Student Senate hereby RESOLVES:   1. To approve the Chairperson of the Judicial Board's appointment of Joshua Berman   as Chairperson of the Judicial Board, effective upon the resignation of the current   Chairperson.       S O  M OVED  B Y   A ND  S ECONDED  B Y   V OTE   Bryan Johns ’19   Meagan Lettko ‘20   17–0–2         P ASSES   |  F AILS           Rensselaer Union   110 8th Street, Troy, NY 12180   sg.rpi.edu  

      MOTION   Rensselaer Union 49th Student Senate   Date: ​  May 2, 2018 |  ​ Motion #4       The Rensselaer Union 49th Student Senate hereby RESOLVES:   1. segments.text: MOTION   Rensselaer Union 49th Student Senate   Date: ​  May 2, 2018 |  ​ Motion #1       WHEREAS Grand Marshal Week 2018 Elections included a number of human errors,   including, but not limited to, the omission of amendments, the appearance of duplicate   names on the ballot, the inclusion of write-in candidates on the ballot, and the omission of   RPI identification checks at polling locations;   WHEREAS, on April 18, 2018, the Elections Commission released a list of its concerns with   the elections, noting that the elections were not tampered by any candidate and that the   results stood as valid;   WHEREAS, on April 22, 2018, the Rensselaer Union Judicial Board ruled that the concerns   with the elections process must be addressed and resolved for subsequent elections; and   WHEREAS the Rensselaer Union Constitution authorizes the Student Senate to establish   and maintain elections policies and procedures;   The Rensselaer Union 49th Student Senate hereby RESOLVES:   1 To establish the Elections Reform Task Force as a special committee of the 49th   Student Senate:   a Its membership shall consist of the Grand Marshal, the Chairperson of the   Elections Commission, the Chairperson of the Web Technologies Group, a   judicial board emeritus, and three members-at-large appointed by the   Grand Marshal, and   b It shall fulfill its purpose and present to the Student Senate, in the form of a   report and resolution, its recommendations by no later than December 31,   2018, and   2 To charge the Elections Reform Task Force with the purposes of:   a Reviewing elections policies, including the  ​ Grand Marshal Week 2018   Elections Handbook ​ , to identify and recommend solutions to any issues with   the elections process, and   Rensselaer Union   110 8th Street, Troy, NY 12180   sg

edu  

      b

Working with the Web Technologies Group, the Rensselaer Union Systems   Administrators and Software Engineers, alumni, and other Union   organizations, to identify and recommend solutions to any technical issues   with the voting system, or to propose an alternative to the current voting   system
S O  M OVED  B Y   A ND  S ECONDED  B Y   V OTE   Nancy Bush  ‘19   Bryan Johns  ‘19   17–0–1         P ASSES   |  F AILS             Rensselaer Union   110 8th Street, Troy, NY 12180   sg

      MOTION   Rensselaer Union 49th Student Senate   Date:  ​ May 2, 2018 |  ​ Motion #2       WHEREAS Jerry Matthews has served the Department of Public Safety for over eight   years, as Director from 2005 to 2009 and as Interim Director from 2014 to 2018;   WHEREAS he has shown a true dedication to not only protecting the students of   Rensselaer, but also engaging with them as an active member of the campus community;   WHEREAS he has played a major role in the expansion and creation of numerous safety   initiatives on campus, including growing the officer escort program during overnight shift   hours, the implementation of a campus-wide active shooter drill, and expanding the   relationship between Public Safety and the Troy Police Department;   WHEREAS he has spearheaded the initiative for Public Safety to participate in extended   outreach to students in order to make the office a more welcoming and approachable   division of campus for students;   WHEREAS his efforts and services will not be forgotten, and he will be missed by many;   The Rensselaer Union 49th Student Senate hereby RESOLVES:   1 To thank Jerry Matthews, Director of Public Safety, for his years of service to the   Rensselaer community, for his commitment to student safety and wellbeing, and   for his continued willingness to support student initiatives and programs,   2 To recognize all of the contributions that he has made to the campus as a whole,   and   3
To wish him the best in his well deserved retirement
